tr.td: Number of tuple inserts, updates, or deletes prior to analyze as a fraction of reltuples.
Minimum number of tuple inserts, updates, or deletes prior to analyze.
Age at which to autovacuum a table to prevent transaction ID wraparound.
Sets the maximum number of simultaneously running autovacuum worker processes.
Multixact age at which to autovacuum a table to prevent multixact wraparound.
Time to sleep between autovacuum runs.
Vacuum cost delay in milliseconds, for autovacuum.
Vacuum cost amount available before napping, for autovacuum.
Number of tuple updates or deletes prior to vacuum as a fraction of reltuples.
Minimum number of tuple updates or deletes prior to vacuum.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Sets the client's character set encoding.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Also controls interpretation of ambiguous date inputs.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
This affects real, double precision, and geometric data types. The parameter value is added to the standard number of digits (FLT_DIG or DBL_DIG as appropriate).
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Sets the display format for interval values.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Shows the character classification and case conversion locale.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Sets the language in which messages are displayed.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Sets the locale for formatting monetary amounts.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Sets the locale for formatting numbers.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Sets the locale for formatting date and time values.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Sets the server (database) character set encoding.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Sets the time zone for displaying and interpreting time stamps.
Client Connection Defaults / Locale and Formatting
Selects a file of time zone abbreviations.

If a dynamically loadable module needs to be opened and the specified name does not have a directory component (i.e., the name does not contain a slash), the system will search this path for the specified file.
Sets the maximum allowed result for exact search by GIN.
This controls the number of consecutive keepalive retransmits that can be lost before a connection is considered dead. A value of 0 uses the system default.
A value of 0 uses the system default.
A value of 0 uses the system default.
Client Connection Defaults / Shared Library Preloading
Lists unprivileged shared libraries to preload into each backend.
Client Connection Defaults / Shared Library Preloading
Lists shared libraries to preload into each backend.
Client Connection Defaults / Shared Library Preloading
Lists shared libraries to preload into server.
Sets the output format for bytea.
Check function bodies during CREATE FUNCTION.
An empty string selects the database's default tablespace.
Sets the default deferrable status of new transactions.
Sets the transaction isolation level of each new transaction.
Sets the default read-only status of new transactions.
Sets the maximum size of the pending list for GIN index.
A value of 0 turns off the timeout.
A value of 0 turns off the timeout.
Sets the schema search order for names that are not schema-qualified.
Sets the session's behavior for triggers and rewrite rules.
A value of 0 turns off the timeout.
Sets the tablespace(s) to use for temporary tables and sort files.
Whether to defer a read-only serializable transaction until it can be executed with no possible serialization failures.
Sets the current transaction's isolation level.
Sets the current transaction's read-only status.
Minimum age at which VACUUM should freeze a table row.
Age at which VACUUM should scan whole table to freeze tuples.
Minimum age at which VACUUM should freeze a MultiXactId in a table row.
Multixact age at which VACUUM should scan whole table to freeze tuples.
Sets how binary values are to be encoded in XML.
Sets whether XML data in implicit parsing and serialization operations is to be considered as documents or content fragments.
Enables advertising the server via Bonjour.
Sets the host name or IP address(es) to listen to.
Sets the maximum number of concurrent connections.
Sets the TCP port the server listens on.
Sets the number of connection slots reserved for superusers.
Sets the directories where Unix-domain sockets will be created.
The owning user of the socket is always the user that starts the server.

Unix-domain sockets use the usual Unix file system permission set. The parameter value is expected to be a numeric mode specification in the form accepted by the chmod and umask system calls. (To use the customary octal format the number must start with a 0 (zero).)
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Sets the maximum allowed time to complete client authentication.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Sets whether Kerberos and GSSAPI user names should be treated as case-insensitive.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Sets the location of the Kerberos server key file.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
When a password is specified in CREATE USER or ALTER USER without writing either ENCRYPTED or UNENCRYPTED, this parameter determines whether the password is to be encrypted.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
When enabled, row security will be applied to all users.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Location of the SSL certificate authority file.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Location of the SSL server certificate file.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Sets the list of allowed SSL ciphers.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Location of the SSL certificate revocation list file.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Sets the curve to use for ECDH.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Location of the SSL server private key file.
Connections and Authentication / Security and Authentication
Give priority to server ciphersuite order.
Allows modifications of the structure of system tables.

Detection of a checksum failure normally causes PostgreSQL to report an error, aborting the current transaction. Setting ignore_checksum_failure to true causes the system to ignore the failure (but still report a warning), and continue processing. This behavior could cause crashes or other serious problems. Only has an effect if checksums are enabled.
It does not prevent updating the indexes, so it is safe to use. The worst consequence is slowness.
This allows attaching a debugger to the process.
This allows attaching a debugger to the process.
Generates debugging output for LISTEN and NOTIFY.
Each level includes all the levels that follow it. The later the level, the fewer messages are sent.
Emit information about resource usage in sorting.

Detection of a damaged page header normally causes PostgreSQL to report an error, aborting the current transaction. Setting zero_damaged_pages to true causes the system to instead report a warning, zero out the damaged page, and continue processing. This behavior will destroy data, namely all the rows on the damaged page.
Sets the server's main configuration file.
Writes the postmaster PID to the specified file.
Sets the time to wait on a lock before checking for deadlock.
The shared lock table is sized on the assumption that at most max_locks_per_transaction * max_connections distinct objects will need to be locked at any one time.
The shared predicate lock table is sized on the assumption that at most max_pred_locks_per_transaction * max_connections distinct objects will need to be locked at any one time.
Shows the size of a disk block.
Shows whether data checksums are turned on for this cluster.
Shows whether the running server has assertion checks enabled.
Shows the maximum number of function arguments.
Shows the maximum number of index keys.
Shows the number of pages per disk file.
Shows the server version as an integer.
Shows the block size in the write ahead log.
Shows the number of pages per write ahead log segment.
Sets the name of the cluster, which is included in the process title.
Enables updating of the process title every time a new SQL command is received by the server.
This algorithm attempts to do planning without exhaustive searching.
GEQO: effort is used to set the default for other GEQO parameters.
Zero selects a suitable default value.
Zero selects a suitable default value.
GEQO: seed for random path selection.
GEQO: selective pressure within the population.
Sets the threshold of FROM items beyond which GEQO is used.
Table scans will be skipped if their constraints guarantee that no rows match the query.
Sets the planner's estimate of the fraction of a cursor's rows that will be retrieved.
This applies to table columns that have not had a column-specific target set via ALTER TABLE SET STATISTICS.
If possible, run query using a parallel worker and with parallel restrictions.
The planner will merge subqueries into upper queries if the resulting FROM list would have no more than this many items.
The planner will flatten explicit JOIN constructs into lists of FROM items whenever a list of no more than this many items would result.
Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of processing each index entry during an index scan.
Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of processing each operator or function call.
Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of processing each tuple (row).
That is, the portion of the kernel's disk cache that will be used for PostgreSQL data files. This is measured in disk pages, which are normally 8 kB each.
Sets the minimum size of relations to be considered for parallel scan.
Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of starting up worker processes for parallel query.
Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of passing each tuple (row) from worker to master backend.
Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of a nonsequentially fetched disk page.
Sets the planner's estimate of the cost of a sequentially fetched disk page.
Enables the planner's use of bitmap-scan plans.
Enables the planner's use of hashed aggregation plans.
Enables the planner's use of hash join plans.
Enables the planner's use of index-only-scan plans.
Enables the planner's use of index-scan plans.
Enables the planner's use of materialization.
Enables the planner's use of merge join plans.
Enables the planner's use of nested-loop join plans.
Enables the planner's use of sequential-scan plans.
Enables the planner's use of explicit sort steps.
Enables the planner's use of TID scan plans.
Number of synchronous standbys and list of names of potential synchronous ones.
Number of transactions by which VACUUM and HOT cleanup should be deferred, if any.
Sets the maximum number of simultaneously defined replication slots.
Sets the maximum number of simultaneously running WAL sender processes.
Sets the number of WAL files held for standby servers.
Sets the maximum time to wait for WAL replication.
Allows connections and queries during recovery.
Allows feedback from a hot standby to the primary that will avoid query conflicts.
Sets the maximum delay before canceling queries when a hot standby server is processing archived WAL data.
Sets the maximum delay before canceling queries when a hot standby server is processing streamed WAL data.
Sets the maximum interval between WAL receiver status reports to the primary.
Sets the maximum wait time to receive data from the primary.
Sets the time to wait before retrying to retrieve WAL after a failed attempt.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Sets the application name to be reported in statistics and logs.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Indents parse and plan tree displays.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Logs each query's rewritten parse tree.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Zero prints all actions. -1 turns autovacuum logging off.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Logs end of a session, including duration.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Logs the duration of each completed SQL statement.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Sets the verbosity of logged messages.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log

By default, connection logs only show the IP address of the connecting host. If you want them to show the host name you can turn this on, but depending on your host name resolution setup it might impose a non-negligible performance penalty.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
If blank, no prefix is used.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Sets the type of statements logged.
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Zero logs all files. The default is -1 (turning this feature off).
Reporting and Logging / What to Log
Sets the time zone to use in log messages.
Reporting and Logging / When to Log
Each level includes all the levels that follow it. The later the level, the fewer messages are sent.
Reporting and Logging / When to Log
Zero prints all queries. -1 turns this feature off.
Reporting and Logging / When to Log
Each level includes all the levels that follow it. The later the level, the fewer messages are sent.
Reporting and Logging / When to Log
Each level includes all the levels that follow it. The later the level, the fewer messages are sent.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Sets the application name used to identify PostgreSQL messages in the event log.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Valid values are combinations of "stderr", "syslog", "csvlog", and "eventlog", depending on the platform.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Can be specified as relative to the data directory or as absolute path.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
The parameter value is expected to be a numeric mode specification in the form accepted by the chmod and umask system calls. (To use the customary octal format the number must start with a 0 (zero).)
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Sets the file name pattern for log files.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Automatic log file rotation will occur after N minutes.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Automatic log file rotation will occur after N kilobytes.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Truncate existing log files of same name during log rotation.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Start a subprocess to capture stderr output and/or csvlogs into log files.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Sets the syslog "facility" to be used when syslog enabled.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Sets the program name used to identify PostgreSQL messages in syslog.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Add sequence number to syslog messages to avoid duplicate suppression.
Reporting and Logging / Where to Log
Split messages sent to syslog by lines and to fit into 1024 bytes.
Number of pages after which previously performed writes are flushed to disk.
For RAID arrays, this should be approximately the number of drive spindles in the array.
Sets the maximum number of parallel processes per executor node.
Maximum number of concurrent worker processes.
A value of -1 disables this feature.
Background writer sleep time between rounds.
Number of pages after which previously performed writes are flushed to disk.
Background writer maximum number of LRU pages to flush per round.
Multiple of the average buffer usage to free per round.
Vacuum cost amount available before napping.
Vacuum cost for a page dirtied by vacuum.
Vacuum cost for a page found in the buffer cache.
Vacuum cost for a page not found in the buffer cache.
Sets the maximum number of simultaneously open files for each server process.
Sets the maximum memory to be used by each autovacuum worker process.
Selects the dynamic shared memory implementation used.
Use of huge pages on Linux.
This includes operations such as VACUUM and CREATE INDEX.
Sets the maximum number of simultaneously prepared transactions.
Sets the maximum stack depth, in kilobytes.
When more tuples than this are present, quicksort will be used.
Sets the number of shared memory buffers used by the server.
Sets the maximum number of temporary buffers used by each session.
Sets the size reserved for pg_stat_activity.query, in bytes.
This much memory can be used by each internal sort operation and hash table before switching to temporary disk files.
Writes executor performance statistics to the server log.
Writes parser performance statistics to the server log.
Writes planner performance statistics to the server log.
Writes cumulative performance statistics to the server log.
Statistics / Query and Index Statistics Collector
Writes temporary statistics files to the specified directory.
Statistics / Query and Index Statistics Collector
Enables the collection of information on the currently executing command of each session, along with the time at which that command began execution.
Statistics / Query and Index Statistics Collector
Statistics / Query and Index Statistics Collector
Collects function-level statistics on database activity.
Statistics / Query and Index Statistics Collector
Collects timing statistics for database I/O activity.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Other Platforms and Clients

When turned on, expressions of the form expr = NULL (or NULL = expr) are treated as expr IS NULL, that is, they return true if expr evaluates to the null value, and false otherwise. The correct behavior of expr = NULL is to always return null (unknown).
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
When turned on, unquoted NULL in an array input value means a null value; otherwise it is taken literally.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
Sets whether "\'" is allowed in string literals.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
Create new tables with OIDs by default.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
Warn about backslash escapes in ordinary string literals.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
Skips privilege checks when reading or modifying large objects, for compatibility with PostgreSQL releases prior to 9.0.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
Emit a warning for constructs that changed meaning since PostgreSQL 9.4.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
When generating SQL fragments, quote all identifiers.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
Causes subtables to be included by default in various commands.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
Causes '...' strings to treat backslashes literally.
Version and Platform Compatibility / Previous PostgreSQL Versions
Sets the shell command that will be called to archive a WAL file.
Allows archiving of WAL files using archive_command.
Forces a switch to the next xlog file if a new file has not been started within N seconds.
Time spent flushing dirty buffers during checkpoint, as fraction of checkpoint interval.
Number of pages after which previously performed writes are flushed to disk.
Sets the maximum time between automatic WAL checkpoints.
Write a message to the server log if checkpoints caused by the filling of checkpoint segment files happens more frequently than this number of seconds. Zero turns off the warning.
Sets the WAL size that triggers a checkpoint.
Sets the minimum size to shrink the WAL to.
Sets the delay in microseconds between transaction commit and flushing WAL to disk.
Sets the minimum concurrent open transactions before performing commit_delay.

The server will use the fsync() system call in several places to make sure that updates are physically written to disk. This insures that a database cluster will recover to a consistent state after an operating system or hardware crash.

A page write in process during an operating system crash might be only partially written to disk. During recovery, the row changes stored in WAL are not enough to recover. This option writes pages when first modified after a checkpoint to WAL so full recovery is possible.
Sets the current transaction's synchronization level.
Sets the number of disk-page buffers in shared memory for WAL.
Compresses full-page writes written in WAL file.
Set the level of information written to the WAL.
Writes full pages to WAL when first modified after a checkpoint, even for a non-critical modifications.
Selects the method used for forcing WAL updates to disk.
Time between WAL flushes performed in the WAL writer.
Amount of WAL written out by WAL writer that triggers a flush.

tr.td: <fetch first row count> in <fetch first clause>
Advanced Information Schema for registered XML Schemas
Advanced support for BINARY and VARBINARY data types
Advanced table mapping: base64 encoding of binary strings
Advanced table mapping: hex encoding of binary strings
Advanced table mapping: null as nil
Advanced table mapping: table as element
Advanced table mapping: table as forest
Advanced table mapping: with target namespace
Alter column data type: XML type
ALTER TABLE statement: DROP COLUMN clause
AS subquery clause in table definition
Basic array support - Arrays of built-in data types
Basic array support - Arrays of distinct types
Basic cursor support - ORDER BY columns need not be in select list
Basic cursor support - Value expressions in ORDER BY clause
Basic cursor support - Positioned UPDATE statement
Basic cursor support - Positioned DELETE statement
Basic cursor support - FETCH statement implicit NEXT
Basic cursor support - WITH HOLD cursors
Basic data manipulation - Searched UPDATE statement
Basic data manipulation - Searched DELETE statement
Basic date and time - DATE data type (including support of DATE literal)
Basic date and time - TIME data type (including support of TIME literal) with fractional seconds precision of at least 0
Basic date and time - TIMESTAMP data type (including support of TIMESTAMP literal) with fractional seconds precision of at least 0 and 6
Basic date and time - Comparison predicate on DATE, TIME, and TIMESTAMP data types
Basic date and time - Explicit CAST between datetime types and character string types
Basic diagnostics management - GET DIAGNOSTICS statement
Basic diagnostics management - SET TRANSACTION statement: DIAGNOSTICS SIZE clause
Basic Information Schema for registered XML Schemas
Basic integrity constraints - NOT NULL constraints
Basic integrity constraints - UNIQUE constraints of NOT NULL columns
Basic integrity constraints - PRIMARY KEY constraints
Basic integrity constraints - Basic FOREIGN KEY constraint with the NO ACTION default for both referential delete action and referential update action
Basic integrity constraints - NOT NULL inferred on PRIMARY KEY
Basic integrity constraints - Names in a foreign key can be specified in any order
Basic joined table - Inner join (but not necessarily the INNER keyword)
Basic joined table - LEFT OUTER JOIN
Basic joined table - RIGHT OUTER JOIN
Basic joined table - Outer joins can be nested
Basic joined table - The inner table in a left or right outer join can also be used in an inner join
Basic joined table - All comparison operators are supported (rather than just =)
Basic LOB data type support - BLOB data type
Basic LOB data type support - CLOB data type
Basic LOB data type support - POSITION, LENGTH, LOWER, TRIM, UPPER, and SUBSTRING functions for LOB data types
Basic LOB data type support - Concatenation of LOB data types
Basic LOB data type support - LOB locator: non-holdable
Basic predicates and search conditions - Comparison predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - BETWEEN predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - IN predicate with list of values
Basic predicates and search conditions - LIKE predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - LIKE predicate ESCAPE clause
Basic predicates and search conditions - NULL predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - Quantified comparison predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - EXISTS predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - Subqueries in comparison predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - Subqueries in IN predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - Subqueries in quantified comparison predicate
Basic predicates and search conditions - Correlated subqueries
Basic predicates and search conditions - Search condition
Basic Privileges - INSERT privilege at the table level
Basic Privileges - UPDATE privilege at the table level
Basic Privileges - UPDATE privilege at the column level
Basic Privileges - REFERENCES privilege at the table level
Basic Privileges - REFERENCES privilege at the column level
Basic query expressions - UNION DISTINCT table operator
Basic query expressions - UNION ALL table operator
Basic query expressions - EXCEPT DISTINCT table operator
Basic query expressions - Columns combined via table operators need not have exactly the same data type
Basic query expressions - Table operators in subqueries
Basic query specification - GROUP BY clause
Basic query specification - GROUP BY can contain columns not in <select list>
Basic query specification - Select list items can be renamed
Basic query specification - Qualified * in select list
Basic query specification - Correlation names in the FROM clause
Basic query specification - Rename columns in the FROM clause
Basic schema manipulation - CREATE TABLE statement to create persistent base tables
Basic schema manipulation - CREATE VIEW statement
Basic schema manipulation - ALTER TABLE statement: ADD COLUMN clause
Basic schema manipulation - DROP TABLE statement: RESTRICT clause
Basic schema manipulation - DROP VIEW statement: RESTRICT clause
Basic schema manipulation - REVOKE statement: RESTRICT clause
Basic SET TRANSACTION statement - SET TRANSACTION statement: ISOLATION LEVEL SERIALIZABLE clause
Basic SET TRANSACTION statement - SET TRANSACTION statement: READ ONLY and READ WRITE clauses
Basic SQL-invoked routines - User-defined functions with no overloading
Basic SQL-invoked routines - User-defined stored procedures with no overloading
Basic table mapping: base64 encoding of binary strings
Basic table mapping: hex encoding of binary strings
Basic table mapping: null as nil
Basic table mapping: table as element
Basic table mapping: table as forest
Basic table mapping: with target namespace
Basic trigger capability - Triggers activated on UPDATE, INSERT, or DELETE of one base table
Basic trigger capability - FOR EACH ROW triggers
Basic trigger capability - Ability to specify a search condition that must be true before the trigger is invoked
Basic trigger capability - Support for run-time rules for the interaction of triggers and constraints
Basic trigger capability - Multiple triggers for the same event are executed in the order in which they were created in the catalog
Character string types - CHARACTER data type
Character string types - CHARACTER VARYING data type
trims trailing spaces from CHARACTER values before counting
Character string types - UPPER and LOWER functions
Character string types - Implicit casting among the character string types
Comma-separated predicates in simple CASE expression
Comparable data types for referential constraints
Create method by specific method name
Default values for IN parameters of SQL-invoked procedures
supported except DEFAULT key word in invocation
Distinct types based on array types
Distinct types based on distinct types
Extended joined table - FULL OUTER JOIN
Extended LIKE clause in table definition
Extended REVOKE statement - REVOKE statement performed by other than the owner of a schema object
Extended REVOKE statement - REVOKE statement: GRANT OPTION FOR clause
Extended REVOKE statement - REVOKE statement to revoke a privilege that the grantee has WITH GRANT OPTION
Extended schema manipulation - ALTER TABLE statement: ALTER COLUMN clause
Extended schema manipulation - ALTER TABLE statement: ADD CONSTRAINT clause
Extended schema manipulation - ALTER TABLE statement: DROP CONSTRAINT clause
Extensions to embedded SQL exception declarations
Features and conformance views - SQL_FEATURES view
Features and conformance views - SQL_SIZING view
Features and conformance views - SQL_LANGUAGES view
FETCH FIRST clause: WITH TIES option
Foreign data wrapper interface routines in Ada
Foreign data wrapper interface routines in C
Foreign data wrapper interface routines in COBOL
Foreign data wrapper interface routines in Fortran
Foreign data wrapper interface routines in MUMPS
Foreign data wrapper interface routines in Pascal
Foreign data wrapper interface routines in PL/I
Full cursor update - Updatable scrollable cursors
Full cursor update - Updatable ordered cursors
Grouped operations - WHERE, GROUP BY, and HAVING clauses supported in queries with grouped views
Grouped operations - Multiple tables supported in queries with grouped views
Grouped operations - Set functions supported in queries with grouped views
Grouped operations - Subqueries with GROUP BY and HAVING clauses and grouped views
Grouped operations - Single row SELECT with GROUP BY and HAVING clauses and grouped views
Host language support for XML: BLOB mapping
Host language support for XML: CLOB mapping
Host language support for XML: CONTENT option
Host language support for XML: DOCUMENT option
Host language support for XML: PRESERVE WHITESPACE option
Host language support for XML: STRIP WHITESPACE option
Host language support for XML: VARCHAR mapping
IN predicate with one list element
INTERSECT table operator - INTERSECT DISTINCT table operator
INTERSECT table operator - INTERSECT ALL table operator

MAX and MIN for row types
consider INSERT ... ON CONFLICT DO UPDATE
Mixed column references in set functions

Named column joins for LOBs, arrays, and multisets
function exists, but some options missing
Null treatment option for LEAD and LAG functions
Null value support (nulls in lieu of values)
Numeric data types - INTEGER and SMALLINT data types
Numeric data types - REAL, DOUBLE PRECISION, and FLOAT data types

Numeric data types - Implicit casting among the numeric data types

Optional key words for default syntax
Overloading of SQL-invoked functions and procedures

SQL comments using leading double minus
SQL paths in function and type name resolution
